text: When he had thus spoken, he spat on the ground, and made clay of the spittle, and he anointed  the eyes of the blind man with the clay,
text_kjv: When he had thus spoken, he spat on the ground, and made clay of the spittle, and he anointed  the eyes of the blind man with the clay,
text_niv: Having said this, he spit on the ground, made some mud with the saliva, and put it on the man’s eyes.
text_esv: Having said these things, he spit on the ground and made mud with the saliva. Then he anointed the man's eyes with the mud
text_nlt: Then he spit on the ground, made mud with the saliva, and spread the mud over the blind man’s eyes.
text_msg: He said this and then spit in the dust, made a clay paste with the saliva, rubbed the paste on the blind man's eyes,
text_nasb: When He had said this, He spat on the ground, and made clay of the spittle, and applied the clay to his eyes,
context: John 9:6 occurs within the larger narrative of Jesus healing a man born blind, recorded in John 9:1-41. This event takes place during Jesus' public ministry in Jerusalem, likely during the Feast of Tabernacles (referenced in John 7-8). The Gospel of John was written by the apostle John around 85-95 AD, primarily for a Gentile audience to demonstrate that Jesus is the Son of God. This healing miracle follows Jesus' declaration in John 8:12 that He is 'the light of the world,' making the restoration of physical sight a powerful metaphor for spiritual illumination. The incident begins when Jesus' disciples ask about the cause of the man's blindness, reflecting common Jewish beliefs about suffering and sin. Jesus corrects their theological misconceptions, explaining that the blindness exists 'so that the works of God might be displayed in him' (9:3). This miracle occurs in a context of increasing opposition from religious leaders who question Jesus' authority and identity. The healing method Jesus employs—using mud made from saliva—is particularly significant given that it was the Sabbath, which would later intensify the controversy. This narrative serves as the sixth of seven miraculous signs in John's Gospel, each designed to reveal Jesus' divine nature and messianic identity. The broader literary context shows John building toward the climactic events of Jesus' death and resurrection, with each miracle serving as evidence of His claims to divinity.
meaning: John 9:6 reveals profound theological truths about Jesus' identity and methodology. The act of spitting on the ground and making mud demonstrates Jesus' sovereignty over creation, echoing God's formation of man from dust in Genesis 2:7. The Hebrew word for 'formed' (yatsar) is the same used for a potter shaping clay, suggesting Jesus is re-creating or completing what was incomplete from birth. The use of saliva, considered unclean by Jewish standards, shows Jesus' willingness to identify with human frailty and work through seemingly humble means. This method also demonstrates that God's power operates independently of human expectations or religious conventions. The Greek word for 'anointed' (epichrio) is related to 'Christ' (Christos), meaning 'anointed one,' subtly reinforcing Jesus' messianic identity. Theologically, this verse illustrates the incarnational principle—God working through physical, earthly means to accomplish spiritual purposes. The mud represents the intersection of divine power and human need, heaven touching earth. This healing method also emphasizes the progressive nature of God's work; healing doesn't always come instantly but through process and obedience. The act reveals Jesus' compassion and personal attention to individual need, showing He doesn't heal from a distance but engages intimately with human suffering. Furthermore, this demonstrates that God's ways are not our ways (Isaiah 55:8-9)—His methods may seem unconventional but are always purposeful. The miracle points to the greater spiritual truth that Jesus opens the eyes of those born in spiritual darkness, bringing light to those who have never seen God's truth.
application: John 9:6 offers rich applications for modern believers navigating faith and daily life. First, it teaches us to trust God's unconventional methods. Just as Jesus used mud and saliva—seemingly insignificant materials—God often works through ordinary circumstances, humble people, or unexpected means to accomplish His purposes. When facing challenges, believers should remain open to how God might work, even if His methods don't align with our preferences or expectations. Second, this verse encourages patience with God's processes. The man had to receive the mud, walk to Siloam, and wash—healing required participation and obedience. Similarly, our spiritual growth and answers to prayer often come through processes that require our active participation and trust. Third, the passage demonstrates God's intimate involvement in our lives. Jesus could have healed from a distance, but He chose physical touch and personal engagement. This reminds us that God cares about our individual circumstances and is personally involved in our healing and growth. Practically, believers can apply this by: engaging in spiritual disciplines even when they seem mundane (prayer, Bible study, fellowship); trusting God's timing when healing or breakthrough seems delayed; looking for God's work in ordinary circumstances rather than only expecting dramatic interventions; and being willing to step out in obedience even when God's instructions seem unusual. For those struggling with physical, emotional, or spiritual blindness, this passage offers hope that God specializes in opening eyes and bringing light to darkness. It also challenges believers to be instruments of healing in others' lives, willing to get involved personally rather than maintaining comfortable distance. The verse reminds us that God's power is not limited by our resources or circumstances—He can use anything to accomplish His purposes. Modern believers should reflect on questions like: 'How is God asking me to trust His unconventional methods?' 'What processes is He inviting me to participate in for my growth or healing?' and 'How can I be more personally engaged in ministering to others' needs?'
prayer: Heavenly Father, like the blind man who received Your healing touch through mud and saliva, I come to You acknowledging my need for Your transforming power. Thank You that You don't work only through impressive means but often use ordinary, humble circumstances to display Your glory. I praise You for Your intimate involvement in my life—that You don't heal from a distance but engage personally with my struggles and needs. Forgive me for the times I've doubted Your methods or grown impatient with Your processes. I confess that I sometimes prefer my own ways over Yours, wanting quick fixes rather than trusting Your perfect timing and means. Thank You for every area where You've already brought healing and sight to my spiritual blindness. I'm grateful that You see potential in what seems broken and incomplete. Lord, I ask for Your continued work in the blind spots of my life—areas where I still can't see clearly or need Your illumination. Help me trust Your unconventional methods and participate obediently in whatever processes You have for my growth. Give me patience when healing seems slow and faith when Your ways don't make sense to me. Use me as an instrument of Your healing in others' lives, willing to get personally involved rather than maintaining comfortable distance. Open my eyes to see Your work in ordinary circumstances and help me recognize Your hand in the everyday moments of life. May Your light shine through me to others who are walking in darkness. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: Jesus' use of mud and saliva serves multiple purposes. Theologically, it echoes God's creation of man from dust (Genesis 2:7), showing Jesus' divine authority over creation. The method also demonstrates that God's power doesn't depend on impressive means—He can use humble, ordinary materials to accomplish extraordinary things. Additionally, this unconventional approach challenged religious expectations and social norms, particularly since it occurred on the Sabbath. The physical act required the man's participation and faith, as he had to allow Jesus to apply the mud and then obey the instruction to wash. This teaches us that God's ways are often different from human expectations (Isaiah 55:8-9), and His methods, though sometimes puzzling, are always purposeful. The intimate, personal nature of the healing also shows God's willingness to engage directly with human suffering rather than remaining distant.
faqs.question: Why did Jesus use such an unusual method of mud and saliva to heal the blind man?

faqs.answer: The healing power wasn't inherent in Jesus' saliva itself, but rather flowed from His divine nature and authority. Throughout the Gospels, Jesus healed through various methods—sometimes with touch, sometimes with words, and sometimes from a distance—demonstrating that the power source was always His divine identity, not the physical means employed. The saliva was simply the vehicle through which His power operated in this instance. In ancient times, saliva was sometimes thought to have medicinal properties, but more importantly, Jesus' use of it showed His willingness to employ humble, even seemingly unclean materials (saliva was considered unclean by Jewish standards) to accomplish God's purposes. This teaches us that God can work through any means He chooses, and His power is not limited by human perceptions of what is appropriate or effective. The focus should remain on Jesus' divine authority rather than the physical components of the miracle.
faqs.question: Was there something special about Jesus' saliva that made it healing?

faqs.answer: Jesus varied His healing methods throughout His ministry, and each approach served specific purposes. In this case, the physical process involving mud, walking to Siloam, and washing served several functions. It required the man's active participation and demonstrated faith through obedience. The method also created a powerful visual metaphor connecting to God's creation of humanity from dust, emphasizing Jesus' role as Creator. Additionally, the process occurred on the Sabbath, which intensified the controversy with religious leaders and forced them to confront Jesus' true identity. The physical nature of the healing also made it undeniable—there was tangible evidence that something supernatural had occurred. Some scholars suggest that different healing methods addressed different aspects of human need: sometimes immediate relief was appropriate, other times a process that built faith and required participation was more beneficial. This teaches us that God's methods are always perfectly suited to accomplish His purposes in each unique situation.
faqs.question: Why didn't Jesus just speak a word of healing like He did in other miracles?

faqs.answer: This passage reveals several important principles about God's work in our lives. First, God often uses ordinary, humble means to accomplish extraordinary purposes—He doesn't always work through impressive or expected methods. Second, God's healing and transformation often involve processes that require our participation and obedience, not just passive reception. Third, God's timing and methods are perfect, even when they don't align with our preferences or understanding. The mud-making process shows that God can use what seems messy or uncomfortable as part of His healing work. For modern believers, this means trusting God's unconventional approaches to our problems, participating actively in the spiritual disciplines and processes He provides, and remaining patient when breakthrough doesn't come instantly. It also encourages us to look for God's work in ordinary circumstances rather than only expecting dramatic interventions. The passage reminds us that God is intimately involved in our healing journey, not distant or detached, and that His power can work through any situation or means He chooses.
faqs.question: What does this healing method teach us about how God works in our lives today?

faqs.answer: This physical healing serves as a powerful metaphor for spiritual salvation and enlightenment. Just as the man was born physically blind, all humans are born spiritually blind due to sin (Ephesians 2:1-3). The healing process illustrates several aspects of salvation: it was initiated by Jesus' compassion, not the man's request; it required receiving what Jesus offered (the mud) even though it might have seemed strange; and it demanded obedient action (going to wash at Siloam). Similarly, salvation comes through God's initiative, requires receiving Christ by faith (even when the gospel seems foolish to human wisdom), and involves obedient response to God's commands. The progression from blindness to sight mirrors the spiritual journey from darkness to light that Jesus brings (John 8:12). The man's growing understanding of Jesus' identity throughout John 9 also reflects how spiritual sight develops progressively as believers grow in their knowledge of Christ. The religious leaders' rejection of the miracle despite clear evidence parallels how spiritual blindness can persist even when confronted with truth, demonstrating that spiritual sight is ultimately a gift from God, not a result of human wisdom or religious status.
faqs.question: How does this miracle relate to spiritual blindness and salvation?
